title: BQTLock and GREENBLOOD: Emerging Ransomware Families Combine Stealth Process Injection, Rapid ChaCha8 Encryption, and TOR-Based Extortion for Maximum Business Disruption

sources.name: ANY.RUN - Emerging Ransomware Threats: BQTLock and GREENBLOOD Analysis

timeline.event: First known BQTLock ransomware samples observed in the wild targeting enterprise environments
GREENBLOOD ransomware operations begin with TOR-based leak site established for double extortion
ANY.RUN publishes comprehensive behavioral analysis of both BQTLock and GREENBLOOD families
Independent researchers publish detailed reverse engineering analysis of both ransomware families
SOCRadar publishes dark web intelligence profile on BQTLock operations and affiliate program
Check Point Research includes BQTLock and GREENBLOOD in weekly threat intelligence report

simple_summary.what_happened: Two new ransomware families have emerged in February 2026, each designed to cause maximum damage in minimum time. BQTLock is a stealth-focused ransomware that hides inside Windows system processes to avoid detection while stealing data and encrypting files. GREENBLOOD is a speed-focused ransomware written in Go that can encrypt entire systems in minutes using military-grade encryption. Both families combine file encryption with data theft and operate leak sites where stolen data is published to pressure victims into paying ransoms.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: All Windows-based organizations are potential targets. Both ransomware families target enterprise environments across multiple industries. Organizations with weak endpoint protection, unpatched systems, or insufficient backup procedures are at highest risk. GREENBLOOD operates a TOR-based leak site for double extortion, meaning even organizations that can recover from encryption face the threat of having sensitive data published publicly.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: BQTLock gains initial access and injects the Remcos remote access trojan directly into explorer.exe, a core Windows process, making the malware invisible to basic security tools. Step 2: It performs a UAC bypass using the legitimate Windows tool fodhelper.exe to silently escalate to administrator privileges without triggering any user prompt. Step 3: With elevated access, BQTLock establishes autorun persistence in the registry and begins harvesting credentials and capturing screenshots for intelligence gathering. Step 4: GREENBLOOD deploys its Go-based payload that uses ChaCha8 encryption (an optimized variant of ChaCha20) to rapidly encrypt files across the network, appending the .tgbg extension. Step 5: Both families exfiltrate stolen data before encryption, then GREENBLOOD self-deletes to hamper forensic analysis while its TOR leak site threatens to publish exfiltrated data unless ransom is paid.
what_you_should_do: Ensure EDR solutions are configured to detect process injection into explorer.exe and UAC bypass via fodhelper.exe
Block known BQTLock IOCs including Remcos C2 infrastructure and associated file hashes at the network perimeter
Verify offline backup integrity and test restoration procedures as GREENBLOOD encryption completes before response teams can react
Monitor for GREENBLOOD indicators including the GREENBLOOD_ENCRYPTOR_MUTEX_ mutex pattern and .tgbg file extensions
Implement network segmentation to limit lateral movement and restrict unnecessary SMB/RDP access between systems
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: These ransomware families represent the evolution of modern ransomware toward maximum impact in minimum time. BQTLock's ability to hide inside legitimate Windows processes makes it extremely difficult to detect with traditional security tools. GREENBLOOD's ChaCha8 encryption can process hundreds of gigabytes per hour, meaning an entire organization can be encrypted in minutes before response teams can intervene. The combination of stealth infiltration, rapid encryption, data theft, and public leak-site extortion creates a multi-layered threat that overwhelms traditional incident response workflows.

tactics.description: BQTLock injects Remcos RAT payload into explorer.exe to execute malicious code within a trusted system process
BQTLock uses fodhelper.exe to bypass UAC and gain elevated administrative privileges without user interaction
BQTLock establishes autorun persistence in Windows registry to survive system reboots
GREENBLOOD performs self-deletion after encryption to reduce forensic evidence and complicate incident response
BQTLock captures screenshots post-escalation for intelligence gathering and to identify high-value targets
Both families exfiltrate stolen data to attacker-controlled infrastructure before initiating encryption
GREENBLOOD uses ChaCha8 encryption to rapidly encrypt files with .tgbg extension; BQTLock encrypts files with .bqtlock extension
GREENBLOOD deletes shadow copies and backup catalogs using wmic shadowcopy delete and wbadmin delete catalog commands

detection_guidance.summary: Focus detection on BQTLock's distinctive process injection and UAC bypass patterns, and GREENBLOOD's unique mutex and file extension indicators. Behavioral detection through sandbox analysis and EDR is essential as both families employ evasion techniques.

log_sources.description: Monitor for process injection events (Event ID 8), registry modifications to Run keys, and fodhelper.exe execution with unusual child processes
Detect Remcos injection into explorer.exe, UAC bypass patterns, ChaCha8 encryption activity, and shadow copy deletion
Monitor for Telegram and Discord webhook C2 communications used by BQTLock, and TOR traffic used by GREENBLOOD
Alert on rapid file modifications with .bqtlock or .tgbg extensions, and creation of READ_ME_TO_RECOVER_FILES.txt ransom notes

what_to_look_for.indicator: Process injection into explorer.exe by unknown parent process
what_to_look_for.description: BQTLock injects Remcos RAT into explorer.exe; any unexpected DLL injection or memory writes to explorer.exe should trigger alerts
BQTLock abuses fodhelper.exe for UAC bypass; this binary should not normally spawn PowerShell, cmd.exe, or other executables
GREENBLOOD creates a mutex with this distinctive prefix to prevent multiple instances; detection of this mutex indicates active encryption

what_to_look_for.indicator: Files being renamed with .tgbg or .bqtlock extensions
what_to_look_for.description: Mass file renaming with these extensions indicates active ransomware encryption in progress

what_to_look_for.indicator: Shadow copy and backup catalog deletion commands
what_to_look_for.description: GREENBLOOD uses wmic shadowcopy delete and wbadmin delete catalog to prevent recovery
what_to_look_for.log_field: command_line CONTAINS 'shadowcopy delete' OR command_line CONTAINS 'wbadmin delete catalog'

what_to_look_for.description: GREENBLOOD drops this ransom note with TOR-based payment and leak site links

immediate_actions.action: Update EDR detection rules for BQTLock and GREENBLOOD indicators
immediate_actions.description: Add detection rules for Remcos injection into explorer.exe, fodhelper.exe UAC bypass, GREENBLOOD_ENCRYPTOR_MUTEX_ mutex pattern, and .tgbg/.bqtlock file extensions

immediate_actions.action: Verify and test offline backup integrity
immediate_actions.description: GREENBLOOD encrypts systems in minutes and deletes shadow copies. Ensure offline backups exist, are current, and restoration has been tested recently
Block Telegram and Discord webhook URLs used by BQTLock for C2 communications at the web proxy or firewall level if not required for business operations
Use application control policies (AppLocker/WDAC) to restrict execution of fodhelper.exe or alert when it spawns child processes, as it is commonly abused for UAC bypass
Restrict SMB and RDP access between workstations and limit lateral movement paths that ransomware uses to spread across the network
